arch:property.oc:show_val: This may be wishful thinking on my part that this is a surface. I dug out the central portion to expose the pottery installation L 9011. The subfloor fill is much the same as the "surface," leading me to believe I may have misnamed this locus. I got the subfloor data from the section we cut out of the floor when removing L 9011. L 9020 will be present to excavate next year as it was closed due to the end of the season. Perhaps then we can determine further if it is in fact a surface.
Cut by large pit and by the pottery installation.
Scrapes into fine particles, fine sort, fine grain size

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

arch:property.oc:show_val: packed earth/hard clay floor--large flat lying sherds. Cut by stone pit L 9011.
Earth much like the surface itself--a hard clay. 7.5 YR 6/3 Light Brown
One course of bricks in the trench, three visible in baulk.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area F / Trench 9 / Locus 9020 (Locus)
